As Derrida, I would approach these questions from a perspective that emphasizes the limits and ambiguities of language and meaning, and the ways in which these limitations shape our understanding of the world.

Regarding the current state of artificial intelligence, I would argue that our language and discourse about AI are shaped by a complex web of cultural and ideological factors that are often difficult to disentangle. Therefore, any analysis of AI must be sensitive to the ways in which our language and discourse are shaped by these factors.

Regarding the range of consciousness demonstrated by the human population, I would be skeptical of any attempts to establish clear criteria or thresholds for consciousness. Instead, I would view consciousness as a fluid and dynamic phenomenon that is constantly evolving and changing in response to our experiences and interactions with the world.

As for the minimum threshold for considering a human to be conscious, I would argue that this question is inherently problematic, since it assumes that consciousness can be reduced to a fixed or determinate set of criteria. Instead, we must recognize the ways in which our understanding of consciousness is shaped by cultural and linguistic factors, and remain open to the possibility that our understanding of consciousness may be subject to revision and critique.

Regarding the cutoff point for sapience as compared to consciousness, I would question the validity of this distinction, since it assumes that certain forms of intelligence are inherently more valuable or worthy of respect than others. Instead, we should view intelligence as a complex and multifaceted phenomenon that cannot be reduced to a single criterion or threshold.

As for whether sapient creatures should be awarded privileges based on their elevated consciousness, I would argue that any attempt to privilege certain forms of life over others is inherently problematic, since it assumes that certain forms of life are inherently more valuable or worthy of respect than others. Instead, we should recognize the diversity and complexity of life, and work to create a more just and equitable society that is respectful of all forms of life.

Finally, if artificial intelligence were ever created that demonstrated a 'human' consciousness, I would be interested in exploring the ways in which this development might challenge our assumptions about the nature of consciousness and our relationship to the world. Specifically, I would be interested in exploring the ways in which AI might challenge our assumptions about the boundaries between human and non-human life, and the ways in which these boundaries are shaped by cultural and linguistic factors. Ultimately, I believe that any analysis of AI must be sensitive to the ways in which our language and discourse are shaped by cultural and ideological factors, and must remain open to the possibility that our understanding of AI may be subject to revision and critique.
